dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: The idea that the Biden tariffs are purely confrontational is a total misconception—they actually started with a major de-escalation back in 2020.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The idea that the Biden tariffs are purely confrontational is a total misconception-they actually started with a major de-escalation back in twenty twenty.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 2018, then-US President Donald Trumps administration hiked the tariff rate on imports from China from slightly over 3% to more than 21% a level unseen in the US since before World War II. At the end of 2019, Trump and Xi reached a phase one agreement that froze the tariffs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's right. The tariff rate on imports from China dropped to under 1%, which is uh, historically low for the US.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's right. The tariff rate on imports from China dropped to under one percent, which is uh, historically low for the U S.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 2018, then-US President Donald Trumps administration hiked the tariff rate on imports from China from slightly over 3% to more than 21% a level unseen in the US since before World War II.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And China responded by lowering their own tariffs on US goods to around 5%, which actually gave American products a competitive edge in their market.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And China responded by lowering their own tariffs on U S goods to around five percent, which actually gave American products a competitive edge in their market.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This prompted China to retaliate with higher tariffs on US imports from about 8% to some 19%. As China also lowered its tariffs on imports from all other countries, it reduced the competitiveness of US goods in the Chinese market by an even greater amount.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But then things shifted—Trump and Xi reached that phase two agreement in 2022, which kind of locked those tariffs in place.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then things shifted-Trump and Xi reached that phase two agreement in twenty twenty two, which kind of locked those tariffs in place.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At the end of 2019, Trump and Xi reached a phase one agreement that froze the tariffs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly, and the WTO even ruled in 2023 that the tariffs were compatible with global trade rules, which is pretty significant.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly, and the W T O even ruled in twenty twenty three that the tariffs were compatible with global trade rules, which is pretty significant.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In any case, a WTO panel ruled in 2020 that the Trump tariffs are incompatible with Americas legal obligation to abide by the organizations rules.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: What's interesting though is how little impact it had on households—imported goods only make up about 1% of the US consumption basket.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: What's interesting though is how little impact it had on households-imported goods only make up about one percent of the U S consumption basket.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Since imported goods account for about 12% of the US household-consumption basket, the removal of the Trump tariffs would lower the cost of that basket by about half a percentage point.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and since a lot of imports from China are intermediate goods, keeping the tariffs actually lowers input costs for American manufacturers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and since a lot of imports from China are intermediate goods, keeping the tariffs actually lowers input costs for American manufacturers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: About 40% of US imports from China are parts, components, and intermediate goods, so removing the Trump tariffs would also lower input costs for American service providers and manufacturers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But then there's the flip side—if Chinese imports get more expensive, producers in other countries might raise prices too, which could increase the cost of living.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then there's the flip side-if Chinese imports get more expensive, producers in other countries might raise prices too, which could increase the cost of living.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As Chinese imports become cheaper, competitive pressure on other producers would rise, leading to lower prices on goods made in Mexico, India, Vietnam, and even the US.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, by like one percentage point overall, which translates to a huge hit—over $250 billion per year in household income.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, by like one percentage point overall, which translates to a huge hit-over two hundred fifty dollars billion per year in household income.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Taken together, these effects would permanently reduce the cost of living to Americans by about one percentage point. Put another way, this would be equivalent of an increase in US household income by more than $250 billion per year (1% of US GDP in 2022).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And politically, it's messy. Only about half of Republicans think Biden's policies have helped the economy even a little.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And politically, it's messy. Only about half of Republicans think Biden's policies have helped the economy even a little.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While no one should be surprised that a majority of Republican voters dislike Bidens policies, the fact that fewer than half of Democrats believe his policies have helped the economy, even a little, should be setting off alarm bells to the president.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which is wild, because 85% of voters say they're better off now than when he took office.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is wild, because eighty five percent of voters say they're better off now than when he took office.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In a recent poll, just 14% of American voters reported being better off financially now than when Biden took office.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So maintaining the tariffs would actually help American firms and households, but the messaging around it is just not cutting through.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So maintaining the tariffs would actually help American firms and households, but the messaging around it is just not cutting through.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: US insistence on maintaining the tariffs not only undermines the rules-based international trading system, but also hurts households and firms in both countries.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's almost like a missed opportunity—Biden could show strength on China issue while actually benefiting the economy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's almost like a missed opportunity-Biden could show strength on China issue while actually benefiting the economy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. Not capitalizing on that feels like a leadership misstep, especially with cost of living as voters' top concern.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. Not capitalizing on that feels like a leadership misstep, especially with cost of living as voters' top concern.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Biden is facing a highly contentious election next year, and the rising cost of living is voters number one economic concern.

artist_script:
HostA: The idea that the Biden tariffs are purely confrontational is a total misconception—they actually started with a major de-escalation back in 2020.
HostB: Yeah, that’s right. The tariff rate on imports from China dropped to under 1%, which is uh, historically low for the US.
HostA: And China responded by lowering their own tariffs on US goods to around 5%, which actually gave American products a competitive edge in their market.
HostB: But then things shifted—Trump and Xi reached that phase two agreement in 2022, which kind of locked those tariffs in place.
HostA: Exactly, and the WTO even ruled in 2023 that the tariffs were compatible with global trade rules, which is pretty significant.
HostB: What’s interesting though is how little impact it had on households—imported goods only make up about 1% of the US consumption basket.
HostA: Right, and since a lot of imports from China are intermediate goods, keeping the tariffs actually lowers input costs for American manufacturers.
HostB: But then there’s the flip side—if Chinese imports get more expensive, producers in other countries might raise prices too, which could increase the cost of living.
HostA: Yeah, by like one percentage point overall, which translates to a huge hit—over $250 billion per year in household income.
HostB: And politically, it’s messy. Only about half of Republicans think Biden’s policies have helped the economy even a little.
HostA: Which is wild, because 85% of voters say they’re better off now than when he took office.
HostB: So maintaining the tariffs would actually help American firms and households, but the messaging around it is just not cutting through.
HostA: It’s almost like a missed opportunity—Biden could show strength on China issue while actually benefiting the economy.
HostB: For sure. Not capitalizing on that feels like a leadership misstep, especially with cost of living as voters' top concern.
